2.05.text:
In fact I suspect most of you will have heard
of one of Scotland's prominent exports in

8.71.text:
the 19th century. A gentleman called Thomas
Carlyle who was known as the Sage of Ecclefechan

15.55.text:
after the town in Dumfriesshire from which
he hailed. Now Thomas Carlyle was a controversial

20.09.text:
figure, he was not an easy man to get on with.
It was said that it was a good thing that

24.22.text:
Thomas married Jane Carlyle because that way
they only made two people miserable rather

28.43.text:
than four. But one of the things about Thomas
Carlyle is that he wrote a book which in a

33.17.text:
way is the theme of today. That book, which
was a bestseller in its time, was called Heroes

43.41.text:
and Hero Worship.
The reason I wanted to take that as my theme

48.10.text:
today is because I have to be honest; I'm
a bit of a hero worshipper of Charlie. I've

54.27.text:
been inspired by his story. I've been impressed
by his commitment and in particular I've been

60.77.text:
moved by the fact that he chose to make his
career as a teacher in some of the toughest

66.30.text:
schools, dealing with some of the most difficult
children in some of the most disadvantaged

70.69.text:
circumstances. He earned his spurs by
making sure that those children, many of whom

77.11.text:
will have been excluded or overlooked by figures
in their life who should really have provided

82.80.text:
them with love and authority - Charlie made
sure that they got the love and the authority

86.72.text:
and the inspiration they deserved to turn
their lives round. Charlie - impressive

92.10.text:
as he is, heroic as he is and brilliant as
he has been in his leadership of the Teaching

96.10.text:
Agency, would be the first to say however
that in a way he's not exceptional, he's typical

103.10.text:
of the people in this room.
The moral purpose that has driven Charlie

108.84.text:
throughout his career, the sense that leadership
is about service and not dictating to others

115.07.text:
and the determination to transform the lives
of children which has been the guiding light

120.18.text:
throughout his life. That moral heroism is
exhibited by everyone in this room. So all

127.55.text:
the praise that I deservedly give to Charlie,
I also want to extend to all of you for all

134.06.text:
that you have done. Now talking of heroes
and hero worship, I have a confession to make

140.48.text:
today. It's only appropriate on the day that
the Archbishop of Canterbury is installed

146.12.text:
and two days after the new Pope has taken
over, that I should be in full confessional

150.45.text:
mode. I know that you will treat this
confession, as all confessions should be treated

155.48.text:
as something which is just between us, totally
private, not for onward transmission.

162.70.text:
So my confession is I don't actually want
to be doing what I'm doing at the moment.

171.55.text:
It's not that I don't enjoy being Education
Secretary, it's a fantastic privilege and

177.42.text:
every day, while it's challenging, is enjoyable.
It's not that I don't appreciate the opportunity

182.99.text:
to work with amazing people, all of you the
fantastic civil servants that I have in the

187.12.text:
DfE and those who support me every day. It's
not that I'm not committed heart and soul

193.66.text:
to transforming our education system; it's
just that I think that politicians like me

200.66.text:
should be doing less and professionals like
you should be you doing more. The fact that

209.29.text:
I intervene as previous Education Secretaries
have intervened all of them, well almost all

214.44.text:
of them, in their own way admiral individuals
driven by a sense of wanting to make this

219.48.text:
country better. The fact that they have intervened
so relentlessly is not because I believe that

225.86.text:
they have been misguided, in many cases they
have been activated by the highest of motivations.

232.29.text:
But the fact that there has been this constant
intervention I believe to an extent has been

237.93.text:
self-defeating.
My aim as Education Secretary is not to pass

244.66.text:
onto whoever may succeed me an appetite for
restless intervention and for determined control

251.34.text:
and for edicts and commands. What I want to
pass on to my successor is a system where

257.97.text:
the leadership is shown not from Sanctuary
Buildings but from the hundreds of outstanding

264.13.text:
schools in the country which really demonstrate
every day what great education looks like.

271.38.text:
So in that sense one of my heroes, to go back
thousands of years in time the same hero funnily

276.56.text:
enough that Boris Johnson had, is a chap called
Cincinnatus who deliberately abjured ambition.

284.45.text:
I'm sure you will all know that he was called
from his estate or in my case my semi-detached

288.83.text:
in North Kensington, to the Plough and he
led Rome during a period when it needed that

294.90.text:
degree of leadership and then he stepped back.
He recognised that if you become too attached

301.27.text:
to the exercise of political power that you
actually end up impoverishing those whom you

307.77.text:
should trust to make a difference.
So my aim during my time as Secretary of State

314.54.text:
is to see the Department for Education reduce,
yes reduce in size so that there are fewer

322.81.text:
people doing a better job, but also reduce
in its reach and scope and interference in

328.45.text:
how you operate every day. Many of you will
have become academy schools and as a result

334.24.text:
you will have felt, I hope, the grip and control
of the DfE and its agencies drawback - there

341.13.text:
when you need them, sometimes not always there
quickly enough when you need them. We know

346.30.text:
that there are some things that the Department
and EFA and others should do more rapidly,

350.19.text:
but the whole point is that we should withdraw
so you can innovate with the curriculum. Train

355.72.text:
teachers in the way that you believe is right.
Provide the right level of professional development.

361.18.text:
Shape collaboration in a way that suits you
not a way that we impose. It's for that

368.49.text:
reason that I believe that over time we can
move towards what my goal is and what the

373.68.text:
theme of this conference is, a self-improving
system where politicians become smaller and

380.59.text:
smaller figures in education and professionals
larger and larger.

386.68.text:
Now I mentioned Cincinnatus and I suppose
if I mention a Roman I'd better mention a

392.19.text:
Greek. The Greek that I want to mention
is Pericles. The reason why I mention

398.26.text:
him is because it seems to me that he sums
up or his career summed up a way of reconciling

404.71.text:
two things which in education are often held
to be somehow at loggerheads. In education

414.14.text:
it's often thought that you can believe in
competition, in striving, in excellence. Or

420.86.text:
you can believe in collaboration, in working
together, in cosiness and that you can't have

427.82.text:
the two. You can't have at the same time that
striving for excellence and that desire to

433.79.text:
help, that actually all of us feel all of
the time. Education in the past, as Michael

442.04.text:
Barber has pointed out has often been bedevilled
by false dichotomies. You either have to believe

448.90.text:
in skills or in knowledge, you either have
to believe in didactic instruction or children

455.13.text:
learning through exploration. Michael
is right to say that these false dichotomies

460.25.text:
help no one. You need both facts and skills;
you need both direct instruction and the opportunity

467.11.text:
for children to construct their own learning
and to explore.

471.00.text:
In the same way you need both that striving
for excellence within your own institution

476.12.text:
and that willingness to help others as well.
Now the reason I mention Pericles is that

481.19.text:
there was a phrase in Greek, a culture in Athens
of what was called 'rivalrous emulation'.

487.37.text:
It sounds like a pompous phrase probably is,
but it's what I want to foster and encourage

493.32.text:
and it's what you do every day. You want your
schools to be outstanding, they are. You feel

498.34.text:
a sense of pride when you see what happens
in your schools and the amazing things that

502.96.text:
children have achieved not just academically
but in sporting terms, culturally and in terms

507.37.text:
of the character that they display when they
leave. You're proud of them, they're proud

512.33.text:
of the school and the parents feel a sense
of pride in what they've achieved as well -

515.92.text:
excellence. But you don't by definition, you
wouldn't be here otherwise, you don't want

522.32.text:
to make that success exclusive. The preserve
of simply those who've been fortunate enough

526.98.text:
to be educated in your school at one time.
You want to help others, and one of the reasons

532.08.text:
why you want to help others is that you want
them to succeed in their own terms and in

537.74.text:
their own way but with your help so that that
can then be an opportunity for you to say

542.61.text:
to your own school, look these were handsome
laurels that we've won but we can't rest on

547.67.text:
them.
It's that culture of combining a belief in

551.24.text:
excellence in your own institution and a desire
to foster collaborative relationships with

556.17.text:
others that lies behind my philosophy for
the Academies Programme and for teaching schools

563.52.text:
and which lay behind the existence of national
leaders of education in the first place. You

568.20.text:
can only become an academy if you're doing
a great job. You can only become a teaching

572.24.text:
school if you're doing an outstanding job.
You can only become an NLE if you've been

575.70.text:
recognised as being someone special. But you
can't keep that designation; you can't simply

583.20.text:
relax in the approval of having secured any
of those laurels without going on to help

590.14.text:
others. A surprising thing to some, but
not to me, is that you don't need massive

597.11.text:
incentives or big sticks. All you need to do
is to trust the instincts of those who are

602.17.text:
currently leading in our schools because what
they want to do overwhelmingly is to support,

608.19.text:
to encourage, certainly to encourage others
to do as well as they've done if not better.

614.00.text:
But one thing that I do know is that sometimes
politicians or their agencies wittingly or

622.12.text:
unwittingly stand in the way of you doing
what you know to be right. One of the concerns

628.75.text:
that was raised with me last week at the Association
of School and College Leaders Conference is

633.46.text:
that there are some people who take on schools
in difficult circumstances and who think,

638.34.text:
do you know what I'm seeking to help but Ofsted
sometimes will pass a judgement prematurely

644.46.text:
before I've had a chance to turn this school
round. Why should I take the risk of moving

649.23.text:
from an already good or an outstanding school
to one that requires improvement or one that's

652.18.text:
in special measures if just as I'm taking
the difficult steps, moving on the staff,

657.09.text:
changing the way in which we operate, dealing
with behaviour that are required, someone comes

661.91.text:
and marks my essay before its complete.
Judges me not even halfway but on the first

668.02.text:
few steps of the journey. There are others
that have also said to me, my school's been

673.15.text:
outstanding, it's outstanding in every area.
But that doesn't happen by accident. Yes I've

679.00.text:
got a great leadership team but I need to
make sure that they're kept up to the mark.

683.27.text:
If I spent time on another school or doing
any of the things that you encourage me to

687.52.text:
and which I want to, then my worry is that
Ofsted will visit and they'll suddenly say

693.07.text:
well do you know what, the time that you've
spent elsewhere lovely though it is, has actually

699.79.text:
had an impact on your own school and we're
going to mark you down. For that act of

705.50.text:
generosity, in fact that act of leadership
on your part, you will somehow suffer. Those

713.39.text:
fears are real but let me tackle them head
on. The person who understands those fears

718.25.text:
best is the Chief Inspector and the person
who's most determined to improve the way in

724.39.text:
which Ofsted operates, to address those fears
is Sir Michael.

728.14.text:
He's another hero of mine, he shares the same
sense of moral purpose that all of you have.

733.24.text:
He is someone who deliberately chose to teach
in the most challenging areas, his career

737.47.text:
was entirely in the state system and he chose
the opportunity when it arose to try to help

742.46.text:
others. So let's work together. Let's make
sure that the framework that we have and the

748.61.text:
way in which it operates ensures that when
you do make that commitment to work with others

754.21.text:
that it is rewarded and acknowledged. I know
Sir Michael wants to introduce ways of recognising

760.81.text:
leadership that goes above and beyond outstanding.
I know that Charlie wants to make sure that

766.22.text:
all the incentives are there and I know that
all the ministers in my department; Lord Nash,

770.81.text:
David Laws and I agree that we need to make
this work. So hold my feet to the fire. If

777.82.text:
I'm still here in six months or in a year's
time in whatever gathering we have, if we

782.33.text:
haven't made the changes necessary in order
to recognise that public spiritedness and

788.48.text:
that leadership, then is the moment to hold
me to account. But in the next 12 months let's

796.19.text:
make sure that the incentives are there.
Talking of heroes and Sir Michael is one,

805.18.text:
there's another one I want to mention too
and that's Franklin Delano Roosevelt. The

811.09.text:
author of the New Deal, the great American
President who was responsible for taking America

816.70.text:
out of depression and who was responsible
also for the victory of democracy in the Second

821.04.text:
World War. Now FDR, when he was elected said
that what he wanted to usher in was not a

826.77.text:
new dawn, not utopia but an era in his own
words 'of bold and restless experimentation'.

834.35.text:
He acknowledged that the situation that he
inherited was far from ideal, but he also

838.28.text:
believed that if it was going to work there
was no master plan that would be unveiled.

842.09.text:
The most important thing to do was to unleash
the talent of others. The new deal succeeded

846.87.text:
not because everything that was implemented
was right, much went wrong. But because he

851.38.text:
trusted people, whether it was in the Tennessee
Valley Authority or those responsible for

855.23.text:
the electrification of the south, to run projects
in a way which would unlock the talent of

860.24.text:
those who had hitherto had their talents neglected
or overlooked or insufficiently stretched.

869.08.text:
In a way our approach at the Department for
Education has been to try and foster as much

874.29.text:
as possible, bold and wherever possible restless
experimentation. Yes we'll produce curricula

882.22.text:
documents, yes I'll give speeches or interviews
and an indication of my thoughts on these

886.54.text:
things, but the most important thing is that
there are developments in how teachers are

892.12.text:
trained, in how the curriculum is applied,
in how children are inspired in your schools.

898.66.text:
What we want to do is to capture those
successes and to ensure that they are disseminated

905.28.text:
more widely but never to condemn those who
do things which may not work out initially,

911.86.text:
but are doing them for the right reasons.
One of the things which I know has sometimes

916.53.text:
been the case in the past is that there's
been a tendency not so much amongst outstanding

920.24.text:
schools but amongst good schools or requires
improvement schools towards risk aversion.

924.10.text:
A desire to swim close to the side of the
swimming pool and never to strike out for

929.40.text:
the deep end. You see that reinforced
sometimes in the way in which people feel

932.96.text:
that the only way in which, when Ofsted comes
to call, that they can escape stricture is

939.19.text:
to do the traditional Ofsted model of a lesson.
The three part lesson with particular types

944.24.text:
of activity delivered in a particular type
of way. All of the things that Michael Wilshaw

947.83.text:
has again made clear is that there is no perfect
lesson, there is no ideal model, good teaching

955.16.text:
occurs in a variety of ways. Sometimes it
will fit a particular template. Sometimes

961.59.text:
there'll be an opportunity for teachers to
digress, diverge to be creative, but provided

969.90.text:
children are engaged and making progress that's
great.

975.85.text:
Again while it's been a problem in the past
that innovation has been constrained, we want

981.60.text:
to encourage it. We want you to take ownership
and that brings me to another hero of mine,

988.26.text:
Dr Ben Goldacre. There was a letter recently,
I think yesterday actually, in the Daily Telegraph,

995.60.text:
and in the Independent from a hundred academics
who were all saying 'what a tragedy that the

1003.74.text:
Education Secretary would like children to
learn things', a huge mistake that. Times tables,

1011.15.text:
vocabulary, spelling, grammar we don't need
any of that in our universities. The impression

1016.17.text:
was created in some minds. This is Gove versus
academia. Actually there's good academia and

1023.17.text:
bad academia. Dr Ben Goldacre sums up to me
the best in academia because the point that

1030.89.text:
he's making is, we now have the means through
research, through randomised control trials,

1037.87.text:
through ways of experimenting to discover
what really works in education and rather

1043.11.text:
than relying on prejudice and worst of all
rather than relying on the whims of politicians

1048.18.text:
who are subject to fashion, let the profession
take control as they have in medicine.

1054.37.text:
Let the profession decide what works. 
Ben made the point, which a number of people

1058.87.text:
have said to me in the past, why should politicians
dictate teaching methods? You wouldn't have

1063.25.text:
the Secretary of State for Health saying how
you should conduct an appendectomy. Well that's

1066.90.text:
true, but in order for us to know exactly
what the most successful ways of raising attainment

1074.41.text:
are what we need to do is to empower the profession.
To experiment to try new ways of working

1081.31.text:
or indeed to go back to some traditional ones
which may have been neglected unfairly and

1086.02.text:
to say this works for us, this is the evidence.
Let's make sure there's a body of evidence

1091.39.text:
from which we can all learn. I think that's
one of the most exciting developments in education

1097.00.text:
at the moment, the belief that we should be
influenced by evidence and the belief

1101.69.text:
above all that those who will generate that
evidence, those that will debate it, those

1106.21.text:
who will learn from it are here in this room,
teachers and teaching leaders.

1111.68.text:
But I also recognise that when talking about
the importance of experimentation, you might

1119.70.text:
sometimes feel well there are some ways actually
Michael that you tie our hands. Let's take

1125.36.text:
one of your wheezers, which a lot of us are
quite keen on - School Direct. The idea that

1130.94.text:
we should play a role in training the next
generation. There you are you've had your

1136.38.text:
side swipe at these academics whom you don't
agree with - fair enough. But actually action

1142.58.text:
speak louder than words Govey and when we
want to train teachers you insist, you absolutely

1149.20.text:
insist that we team up with a higher education
institution where some of these people are

1156.52.text:
and that they're the people who get the cash
not us. I thought you trusted us, I thought

1162.16.text:
you wanted a self-improving profession. I
thought you wanted those in the classroom

1166.93.text:
who are exhibiting great leadership to be
in control and I do.

1171.49.text:
One of the things that I want to see over
the course of the next two years is a move

1176.43.text:
away from a reliance on higher education institutions
determining what should be happening in terms

1184.08.text:
of teacher training and increasingly towards
you. That's why today we're making an

1189.19.text:
additional £10 million available in order
to ensure that you can play a bigger role

1195.44.text:
in School Direct. Because I believe that it's
in your schools that the top graduates can

1203.62.text:
become the outstanding teachers of tomorrow.
I also know that contrary to what some of

1209.86.text:
us have said in the past, that the very best
school based initial teacher training is the

1214.39.text:
best teacher training in the country.
There is more and more evidence that people

1219.71.text:
want to go as soon as possible after graduating
in whatever subject it may have been that

1224.43.text:
they were an undergraduate - the best people
want to go into the best schools. The

1229.08.text:
success of School Direct so far, the number
of top graduates who want to go in has been

1233.38.text:
hugely encouraging for me.
Now having a first, having a 2.1 is not everything.

1238.95.text:
There are some great teachers who haven't
necessarily been to some of the posher universities

1245.44.text:
with lustre and all the rest of it. However
one thing that we all recognise is that over

1251.30.text:
the last 10 years it's been a really good
thing that more top graduates from great universities

1258.39.text:
with real subject knowledge and a passion
for education have come into the classroom

1262.56.text:
and into the profession. That is something
we want to encourage not discourage and that

1268.42.text:
is one of the things that School Direct has
helped accelerate. It's partly due to what's

1273.45.text:
happened beforehand, it's partly due to the
leadership and the example that you've set,

1276.99.text:
it's partly due to the leadership and example
of Charlie. But we now have more people particularly

1283.15.text:
in shortage subjects who have great degrees,
who really want to go into teaching and who

1289.15.text:
School Direct is helping. I think that
the additional money that we're making available

1293.51.text:
today is a sign in earnest, that we want to
move in the direction of empowering you.

1301.61.text:
Now I began by mentioning Thomas Carlyle and
people might think that's all too revealing,

1306.80.text:
he quotes a Victorian, he quotes these figures
from Ancient Greece and Rome, that's all Govey

1312.32.text:
cares about. Indeed there was a revealing
moment last week I'm afraid at the ASCR Conference

1316.82.text:
on 15 March when I was asked what day is it
today? I said, it's the Ides of March.

1326.41.text:
Then Gerard Kelly of the TES said 'well I think
more people might recognise that today is

1330.05.text:
Red Nose Day Michael'. I thought that he'd
constructed the perfect trap and I'd fallen

1337.38.text:
into it. But the truth is that while yes I
love history, some people might think too

1345.12.text:
much, I'm also far more excited about the
future. I'm particularly excited about the

1350.81.text:
fact that change is happening quickly in English
education thanks to all of you.

1357.03.text:
I have the opportunity whenever I travel abroad
or whenever I talk to other government ministers

1361.19.text:
to boast, not about what I'm achieving but
about what you're achieving. Speeches that

1366.75.text:
I give to external audiences are always studded
with the successes of schools in England now.

1375.09.text:
All of them state schools, some of them Academies,
almost all of them represented here.

1379.58.text:
The reason that I enjoy boasting is because I
feel a sense of pride and excitement about

1385.76.text:
the way in which England, your schools are
pioneering new ways of making sure that children

1391.89.text:
can do better than ever. There are lots of
things to be proud of in England's past but

1396.59.text:
there is one thing of which we should be ashamed.
Over our history England has always been great

1403.48.text:
at educating an elite well and terrible at
making sure that education promotes equality

1410.50.text:
and social mobility - until recently.
Thanks to the leadership that people like

1415.71.text:
you have shown at last even as the bar is
being raised the gap is being closed.

1422.91.text:
Thanks to what you have done my belief which
is that education can overcome the disadvantages

1429.91.text:
of environment, or the difficulties caused
by poverty is being proven. The reason I believe

1437.14.text:
so powerfully that schools can make a difference
to our society is that I believe in the power

1442.41.text:
of teaching to inspire and to transform lives.
You demonstrate that every day, which is

1449.25.text:
why ultimately in any speech about heroes
and hero worship I have to acknowledge, you

1455.84.text:
are the heroes and it's a pleasure to have
this opportunity to give you more power.
